                    <a data-pjax="true" title="Update Mastodon to Rails 6.1 (#15910)

* Update devise-two-factor to unreleased fork for Rails 6 support

Update tests to match new `rotp` version.

* Update nsa gem to unreleased fork for Rails 6 support

* Update rails to 6.1.3 and rails-i18n to 6.0

* Update to unreleased fork of pluck_each for Ruby 6 support

* Run "rails app:update"

* Add missing ActiveStorage config file

* Use config.ssl_options instead of removed ApplicationController#force_ssl

Disabled force_ssl-related tests as they do not seem to be easily testable
anymore.

* Fix nonce directives by removing Rails 5 specific monkey-patching

* Fix fixture_file_upload deprecation warning

* Fix yield-based test failing with Rails 6

* Use Rails 6's index_with when possible

* Use ActiveRecord::Cache::Store#delete_multi from Rails 6

This will yield better performances when deleting an account

* Disable Rails 6.1's automatic preload link headers

Since Rails 6.1, ActionView adds preload links for javascript files
in the Links header per default.

In our case, that will bloat headers too much and potentially cause
issues with reverse proxies. Furhermore, we don't need those links,
as we already output them as HTML link tags.

* Switch to Rails 6.0 default config

* Switch to Rails 6.1 default config

* Do not include autoload paths in the load path" class="Link--secondary" href="/hometown-fork/hometown/commit/cbd0ee1d07c0d48e4ed14bd446cd23d334e76da8">Update Mastodon to Rails 6.1 (</a><a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="832181459" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/15910" data-hovercard-type="pull_request" data-hovercard-url="/mastodon/mastodon/pull/15910/hovercard" href="https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/pull/15910">mastodon#15910</a><a data-pjax="true" title="Update Mastodon to Rails 6.1 (#15910)

Disabled force_ssl-related tests as they do not seem to be easily testable
anymore.

* Fix nonce directives by removing Rails 5 specific monkey-patching

* Fix fixture_file_upload deprecation warning

* Fix yield-based test failing with Rails 6

* Use Rails 6's index_with when possible

                    <a data-pjax="true" title="Remove support for OAUTH_REDIRECT_AT_SIGN_IN (#17287)

Fixes #15959

Introduced in #6540, OAUTH_REDIRECT_AT_SIGN_IN allowed skipping the log-in form
to instead redirect to the external OmniAuth login provider.

However, it did not prevent the log-in form on /about introduced by #10232 from
appearing, and completely broke with the introduction of #15228.

As I restoring that previous log-in flow without introducing a security
vulnerability may require extensive care and knowledge of how OmniAuth works,
this commit removes support for OAUTH_REDIRECT_AT_SIGN_IN instead for the time
being." class="Link--secondary" href="/hometown-fork/hometown/commit/cfa583fa7111cfc16b9ce548f9d9b58963f154bd">Remove support for OAUTH_REDIRECT_AT_SIGN_IN (</a><a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="1101935417" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/17287" data-hovercard-type="pull_request" data-hovercard-url="/mastodon/mastodon/pull/17287/hovercard" href="https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/pull/17287">mastodon#17287</a><a data-pjax="true" title="Remove support for OAUTH_REDIRECT_AT_SIGN_IN (#17287)

Fixes #15959

Introduced in #6540, OAUTH_REDIRECT_AT_SIGN_IN allowed skipping the log-in form
to instead redirect to the external OmniAuth login provider.

However, it did not prevent the log-in form on /about introduced by #10232 from
appearing, and completely broke with the introduction of #15228.

As I restoring that previous log-in flow without introducing a security
vulnerability may require extensive care and knowledge of how OmniAuth works,
this commit removes support for OAUTH_REDIRECT_AT_SIGN_IN instead for the time
being." class="Link--secondary" href="/hometown-fork/hometown/commit/cfa583fa7111cfc16b9ce548f9d9b58963f154bd">)</a>
              </span>

                    <a data-pjax="true" title="Bump webpacker from 4.0.7 to 4.2.0 (#12416)

* Bump webpacker from 4.0.7 to 4.2.0

Bumps [webpacker](https://github.com/rails/webpacker) from 4.0.7 to 4.2.0.
- [Release notes](https://github.com/rails/webpacker/releases)

                    <a data-pjax="true" title="Replace deprecated String.prototype.substr() (#17949)

* Replace deprecated String.prototype.substr()

.substr() is deprecated so we replace it with .slice() which works similarily but isn't deprecated

* Change String.prototype.substring() to String.prototype.slice()

.substring() and .slice() work very similary but .slice() is a bit faster and stricter

* Add ESLint rule to forbid usage of .substr and .substring

.substr() is deprecated and .substring() is very similar to .slice() so better to use .slice() at all times

Signed-off-by: Tobias Speicher <rootcommander@gmail.com>" class="Link--secondary" href="/hometown-fork/hometown/commit/0ec695e036dab45d57598f451266bd0b176df9fd">Replace deprecated String.prototype.substr() (</a><a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="1190940651" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/17949" data-hovercard-type="pull_request" data-hovercard-url="/mastodon/mastodon/pull/17949/hovercard" href="https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/pull/17949">mastodon#17949</a><a data-pjax="true" title="Replace deprecated String.prototype.substr() (#17949)

.substr() is deprecated so we replace it with .slice() which works similarily but isn't deprecated

* Change String.prototype.substring() to String.prototype.slice()

.substring() and .slice() work very similary but .slice() is a bit faster and stricter

* Add ESLint rule to forbid usage of .substr and .substring

Signed-off-by: Tobias Speicher <rootcommander@gmail.com>" class="Link--secondary" href="/hometown-fork/hometown/commit/0ec695e036dab45d57598f451266bd0b176df9fd">)</a>

* Replace browserify with webpack

* Add react-intl-translations-manager

* Do not minify in development, add offline-plugin for ServiceWorker background cache updates

* Adjust tests and dependencies

* Fix production deployments

* Fix tests

* More optimizations

* Improve travis cache for npm stuff

* Re-run travis

* Add back support for custom.scss as before

* Remove offline-plugin and babili

* Fix issue with Immutable.List().unshift(...values) not working as expected

* Make travis load schema instead of running all migrations in sequence

* Fix missing React import in WarningContainer. Optimize rendering performance by using ImmutablePureComponent instead of
React.PureComponent. ImmutablePureComponent uses Immutable.is() to compare props. Replace dynamic callback bindings in
<UI />

                    <a data-pjax="true" title="Add .gitattributes file to avoid unwanted CRLF (#3954)

When Windows checks out files, it defaults to changing line endings to CRLF. If these files are then copied to a Linux system to be run, and the endings aren't changed at some point in that process, things break. This file forces git to use LF for all text files on all systems (except the request testing specfiles) to prevent issues everywhere." class="Link--secondary" href="/hometown-fork/hometown/commit/7aeb9168b01971e4e2c4c9b757dff09638b171ac">Add .gitattributes file to avoid unwanted CRLF (</a><a class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-error-text="Failed to load title" data-id="238463454" data-permission-text="Title is private" data-url="https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/3954" data-hovercard-type="pull_request" data-hovercard-url="/mastodon/mastodon/pull/3954/hovercard" href="https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/pull/3954">mastodon#3954</a><a data-pjax="true" title="Add .gitattributes file to avoid unwanted CRLF (#3954)

            <h2 class="Box-title">

          <div data-target="readme-toc.content" class="Box-body px-5 pb-5">
            <article class="markdown-body entry-content container-lg" itemprop="text"><h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-hometown-a-mastodon-fork" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#hometown-a-mastodon-fork"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Hometown: a Mastodon fork</h1>
<p dir="auto"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/1affcf58842d9b19a69f38caf783156b0003fa80e3e532cd418df4e1215c70af/68747470733a2f2f6c6976652e737461746963666c69636b722e636f6d2f373030352f32363737373333393034325f623332636566346531665f622e6a7067"><img width="300" src="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/1affcf58842d9b19a69f38caf783156b0003fa80e3e532cd418df4e1215c70af/68747470733a2f2f6c6976652e737461746963666c69636b722e636f6d2f373030352f32363737373333393034325f623332636566346531665f622e6a7067" alt="photo of a village of stone huts nestled in a lush green valley" data-canonical-src="https://live.staticflickr.com/7005/26777339042_b32cef4e1f_b.jpg" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">Photo by <a href="https://www.flickr.com/photos/141654969@N04/26777339042/" rel="nofollow">Joana Mujollari</a>, CC0 / Public Domain.</p>
<p dir="auto">Mastodon is a <strong>free, open-source social network server</strong> based on ActivityPub. This is <em>not</em> the official version of Mastodon; this is a separate version (i.e. a fork) maintained by <a href="https://friend.camp/@darius" rel="nofollow">Darius Kazemi</a>. For more information on Mastodon, you can see the <a href="https://joinmastodon.org" rel="nofollow">official website</a> and the <a href="https://github.com/tootsuite/mastodon">upstream repo</a>.</p>
<p dir="auto"><strong>Hometown</strong> is a light weight fork of Mastodon. This fork is based on the principle of: minimum code change for maximum user experience change. By our best understanding, our major changes are not wanted by the Mastodon project, hence maintaining this fork instead of trying to commit the changes to Mastodon.</p>
<p dir="auto">Please <a href="https://github.com/hometown-fork/hometown/wiki">check out our wiki</a> for a list of Hometown-exclusive features. Some but not all of these are covered in this document.</p>
<p dir="auto">You can also find <a href="https://github.com/hometown-fork/hometown/wiki/Hometown-servers">a list of running Hometown instances</a>, don't hesitate to open an issue to add yours!</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-support-this-project" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#support-this-project"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Support this project</h2>
<p dir="auto">Please consider <a href="https://www.patreon.com/tinysubversions" rel="nofollow">supporting Hometown by pledging to my Patreon</a>, which supports all my open source projects including this one!</p>
<p dir="auto">Of course this project couldn't exist without Mastodon so maybe <a href="https://www.patreon.com/mastodon" rel="nofollow">support the Mastodon project Patreon</a> too.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-migrating-from-mastodon-to-hometown" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#migrating-from-mastodon-to-hometown"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Migrating from Mastodon to Hometown</h2>
<p dir="auto">Please see <a href="https://github.com/hometown-fork/hometown/wiki/Initial-migration">this article in the wiki</a> for directions on migration from Mastodon to Hometown.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-local-only-posting" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#local-only-posting"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Local only posting</h2>
<p dir="auto">Mastodon right now is designed to get your messages out to the entire fediverse. This is great, but there is a huge need for more private communities. And in a federated network I think it makes the most sense for your home server to be that community (hence "Hometown").</p>
<p dir="auto"><strong>In the context of Hometown, local only posting is a per-post security option that lets you set whether that post can federate out to other servers or not.</strong></p>
<p dir="auto">I've been running Friend Camp, a Mastodon fork with local only posting, for about a year. Being able to have conversations with people on your server that don't federate is a hugely liberating thing. It allows inside jokes to develop. It allows people the freedom to complain about things that they wouldn't necessarily feel comfortable leaving a trusted server (cops, employers, etc). It also lets us do things like have a server-wide movie night where we flood the local timeline with posts about the movie, and it doesn't pollute the rest of the Fediverse.</p>
<p dir="auto">This feature is based on <a href="https://github.com/tootsuite/mastodon/pull/8427" data-hovercard-type="pull_request" data-hovercard-url="/mastodon/mastodon/pull/8427/hovercard">the work of Renato Lond</a>, which is itself based on a feature in the <a href="https://glitch-soc.github.io/docs/" rel="nofollow">Mastodon Glitch Edition</a> fork.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-reading-more-content-types" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#reading-more-content-types"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Reading more content types</h2>
<p dir="auto">Mastodon is microblogging software, meant for Twitter-style shortform posting.</p>
<p dir="auto">Hometown is microblogging for <em>writing</em>, but its goal is to accept many content types for <em>reading</em>. So while I don't plan to let Hometown users publish massive blog posts, I would like your Hometown instance to be your one-stop shop for viewing all sorts of things on the Fediverse.</p>
<p dir="auto">For Hometown this means if you subscribe to a service that sends out <code>Article</code> objects over ActivityPub (such as a blog on <a href="https://write.as" rel="nofollow">Write As</a>), then those full articles render in your home timeline, behind a cut for length. Also, Hometown will render a variety of rich text like <em>italic</em> and <strong>bold</strong>.</p>
<p dir="auto">Click on this GIF for a brief video demo:</p>
<p dir="auto"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/bfaea744c064709f34ad5229074d65f9d97753b0f63d294dedda4f007b4856da/687474703a2f2f74696e7973756276657273696f6e732e636f6d2f706963732f686f6d65746f776e2d61727469636c652e676966"><img src="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/bfaea744c064709f34ad5229074d65f9d97753b0f63d294dedda4f007b4856da/687474703a2f2f74696e7973756276657273696f6e732e636f6d2f706963732f686f6d65746f776e2d61727469636c652e676966" alt="Video demo of someone clicking 'read article' on an incoming article post, which then renders a full article." data-animated-image="" data-canonical-src="http://tinysubversions.com/pics/hometown-article.gif" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">This is based on rich text work by <a href="https://sitedethib.com" rel="nofollow">Claire Girka</a>, and my own work on <code>Article</code> support.</p>
<h3 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-its-more-than-just-reading-more-stuff" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#its-more-than-just-reading-more-stuff"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>It's more than just reading more stuff</h3>
<p dir="auto">Reading more content types also helps make the fediverse better. ActivityPub supports all kinds of content, but most ActivityPub servers shoehorn all their content into <code>Note</code> because that's the type that Mastodon treats as first-class. This has important implications for the fediverse and also on your day to do user experience.</p>
<p dir="auto">Take the "quote tweet" debate for example.</p>
<p dir="auto">Twitter has a feature called "quote tweeting" that lets you embed what someone else tweets, with your own comment right next to it. It's really useful for provide commentary in context, like this, where I point people to a sale and they can read both my comment on the sale and the original tweet about the sale in one post:</p>
<p dir="auto"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/1c074a7c5c4ea35a34b6b02dbe09e1771a3903a9776c0211c75ef1c9c679bf03/687474703a2f2f74696e7973756276657273696f6e732e636f6d2f706963732f71756f74652d74776565742e706e67"><img width="600" src="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/1c074a7c5c4ea35a34b6b02dbe09e1771a3903a9776c0211c75ef1c9c679bf03/687474703a2f2f74696e7973756276657273696f6e732e636f6d2f706963732f71756f74652d74776565742e706e67" alt="An example of a quote tweet from Twitter." data-canonical-src="http://tinysubversions.com/pics/quote-tweet.png" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<blockquote>
<p dir="auto">Hometown doesn't support quoting articles yet... but it will.</p>
</blockquote>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-better-list-management" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#better-list-management"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Better list management</h2>
<p dir="auto">If Hometown is going to be a universal reader, you're going to need better control over organizing your feeds than mainline Mastodon provides.</p>
<p dir="auto">I've introduced a new kind of <a href="https://github.com/hometown-fork/hometown/wiki/Exclusive-lists">exclusive list</a>. In vanilla Mastodon, if you add an account to your "friends I like" list, posts from people on that list appear on that list. But they also appear on your home timeline, and maybe you don't want that! You'd rather treat your "friends I like" list as your "real" home timeline, and then check your home timeline when you're bored. Check out <a href="https://github.com/hometown-fork/hometown/wiki/Exclusive-lists">more details about exclusive lists on the wiki</a>.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-better-accessibility-defaults" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#better-accessibility-defaults"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Better accessibility defaults</h2>
<p dir="auto">Look, right now this pretty much just means that we underline hyperlinks by default. I'm of course open to implementing other obviously beneficial accessibilty defaults that Mastodon itself doesn't implement.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-hometown-is-still-99999-mastodon" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#hometown-is-still-99999-mastodon"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Hometown is still 99.999% Mastodon</h2>
<p dir="auto">I don't intend to stray very far from mainline Mastodon with this fork. If you want something that provides a ton of new features and widgets and stuff, the <a href="https://glitch-soc.github.io/docs/" rel="nofollow">Mastodon Glitch Edition</a> fork is a wondrous kitchen sink of major and minor tweaks.</p>
<p dir="auto">Part of why I don't want to stray far from mainline Mastodon is that this project is going to be just me for the foreseeable future, and I'd like to keep it up to date with new Mastodon versions as easily as possible. The less code I change from Mastodon, the easier that is. Hence the principle of "minimum code change for maximum user experience change."</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-versioning" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#versioning"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Versioning</h2>
<p dir="auto">Hometown uses <a href="https://semver.org" rel="nofollow">semantic versioning</a> and follows a versioning convention like <code>v1.0.0+2.9.3</code>. The 1.0.0 part is the actual Hometown version number, and then the 2.9.3 after the + sign is what's known in semantic versioning as "build metadata". It just means that a particular release is synchronized with Mastodon version 2.9.3, so for example an upgrade from <code>v1.0.0+2.9.2</code> to <code>v1.0.0+2.9.3</code> would upgrade <em>Mastodon</em> but not provide any new Hometown features or fixes.</p>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-contributing-to-hometown" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#contributing-to-hometown"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Contributing to Hometown</h2>
<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-setting-up-your-hometown-development-environment-is-exactly-like-setting-up-your-mastodon-development-environment-pull-requests-should-be-made-to-the-hometown-dev-branch-which-is-our-default-branch-in-github" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#setting-up-your-hometown-development-environment-is-exactly-like-setting-up-your-mastodon-development-environment-pull-requests-should-be-made-to-the-hometown-dev-branch-which-is-our-default-branch-in-github"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M7.775 3.275a.75.75 0 001.06 1.06l1.25-1.25a2 2 0 112.83 2.83l-2.5 2.5a2 2 0 01-2.83 0 .75.75 0 00-1.06 1.06 3.5 3.5 0 004.95 0l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95-4.95l-1.25 1.25zm-4.69 9.64a2 2 0 010-2.83l2.5-2.5a2 2 0 012.83 0 .75.75 0 001.06-1.06 3.5 3.5 0 00-4.95 0l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 004.95 4.95l1.25-1.25a.75.75 0 00-1.06-1.06l-1.25 1.25a2 2 0 01-2.83 0z"></path></svg></a>Setting up your Hometown development environment is <a href="https://docs.joinmastodon.org/dev/overview/" rel="nofollow">exactly like setting up your Mastodon development environment</a>. Pull requests should be made to the <code>hometown-dev</code> branch, which is our default branch in Github.</h1>
<p dir="auto">You can open issues for bugs you've found or features you think are missing. You can also submit pull requests to this repository or submit translations using Crowdin. To get started, take a look at <a href="/hometown-fork/hometown/blob/hometown-dev/CONTRIBUTING.md">CONTRIBUTING.md</a>. If your contributions are accepted into Mastodon, you can request to be paid through <a href="https://opencollective.com/mastodon" rel="nofollow">our OpenCollective</a>.</p>
<p dir="auto"><strong>IRC channel</strong>: #mastodon on irc.libera.chat</p>

readabilityObject.title: GitHub - hometown-fork/hometown: A supported fork of Mastodon that provides local posting and a wider range of content types.
readabilityObject.content:
Hometown: a Mastodon fork

Photo by Joana Mujollari, CC0 / Public Domain.

Mastodon is a free, open-source social network server based on ActivityPub. This is not the official version of Mastodon; this is a separate version (i.e. a fork) maintained by Darius Kazemi. For more information on Mastodon, you can see the official website and the upstream repo.

Hometown is a light weight fork of Mastodon. This fork is based on the principle of: minimum code change for maximum user experience change. By our best understanding, our major changes are not wanted by the Mastodon project, hence maintaining this fork instead of trying to commit the changes to Mastodon.

Please check out our wiki for a list of Hometown-exclusive features. Some but not all of these are covered in this document.

You can also find a list of running Hometown instances, don't hesitate to open an issue to add yours!

Support this project

Please consider supporting Hometown by pledging to my Patreon, which supports all my open source projects including this one!

Of course this project couldn't exist without Mastodon so maybe support the Mastodon project Patreon too.

Migrating from Mastodon to Hometown

Please see this article in the wiki for directions on migration from Mastodon to Hometown.

Local only posting

Mastodon right now is designed to get your messages out to the entire fediverse. This is great, but there is a huge need for more private communities. And in a federated network I think it makes the most sense for your home server to be that community (hence "Hometown").

In the context of Hometown, local only posting is a per-post security option that lets you set whether that post can federate out to other servers or not.

I've been running Friend Camp, a Mastodon fork with local only posting, for about a year. Being able to have conversations with people on your server that don't federate is a hugely liberating thing. It allows inside jokes to develop. It allows people the freedom to complain about things that they wouldn't necessarily feel comfortable leaving a trusted server (cops, employers, etc). It also lets us do things like have a server-wide movie night where we flood the local timeline with posts about the movie, and it doesn't pollute the rest of the Fediverse.

This feature is based on the work of Renato Lond, which is itself based on a feature in the Mastodon Glitch Edition fork.

Reading more content types

Mastodon is microblogging software, meant for Twitter-style shortform posting.

Hometown is microblogging for writing, but its goal is to accept many content types for reading. So while I don't plan to let Hometown users publish massive blog posts, I would like your Hometown instance to be your one-stop shop for viewing all sorts of things on the Fediverse.

For Hometown this means if you subscribe to a service that sends out Article objects over ActivityPub (such as a blog on Write As), then those full articles render in your home timeline, behind a cut for length. Also, Hometown will render a variety of rich text like italic and bold.

Click on this GIF for a brief video demo:

This is based on rich text work by Claire Girka, and my own work on Article support.

It's more than just reading more stuff

Reading more content types also helps make the fediverse better. ActivityPub supports all kinds of content, but most ActivityPub servers shoehorn all their content into Note because that's the type that Mastodon treats as first-class. This has important implications for the fediverse and also on your day to do user experience.

Take the "quote tweet" debate for example.

Twitter has a feature called "quote tweeting" that lets you embed what someone else tweets, with your own comment right next to it. It's really useful for provide commentary in context, like this, where I point people to a sale and they can read both my comment on the sale and the original tweet about the sale in one post:

Hometown doesn't support quoting articles yet... but it will.

Better list management

If Hometown is going to be a universal reader, you're going to need better control over organizing your feeds than mainline Mastodon provides.

I've introduced a new kind of exclusive list. In vanilla Mastodon, if you add an account to your "friends I like" list, posts from people on that list appear on that list. But they also appear on your home timeline, and maybe you don't want that! You'd rather treat your "friends I like" list as your "real" home timeline, and then check your home timeline when you're bored. Check out more details about exclusive lists on the wiki.

Better accessibility defaults

Look, right now this pretty much just means that we underline hyperlinks by default. I'm of course open to implementing other obviously beneficial accessibilty defaults that Mastodon itself doesn't implement.

Hometown is still 99.999% Mastodon

I don't intend to stray very far from mainline Mastodon with this fork. If you want something that provides a ton of new features and widgets and stuff, the Mastodon Glitch Edition fork is a wondrous kitchen sink of major and minor tweaks.

Part of why I don't want to stray far from mainline Mastodon is that this project is going to be just me for the foreseeable future, and I'd like to keep it up to date with new Mastodon versions as easily as possible. The less code I change from Mastodon, the easier that is. Hence the principle of "minimum code change for maximum user experience change."

Versioning

Hometown uses semantic versioning and follows a versioning convention like v1.0.0+2.9.3. The 1.0.0 part is the actual Hometown version number, and then the 2.9.3 after the + sign is what's known in semantic versioning as "build metadata". It just means that a particular release is synchronized with Mastodon version 2.9.3, so for example an upgrade from v1.0.0+2.9.2 to v1.0.0+2.9.3 would upgrade Mastodon but not provide any new Hometown features or fixes.

Contributing to Hometown

Setting up your Hometown development environment is exactly like setting up your Mastodon development environment. Pull requests should be made to the hometown-dev branch, which is our default branch in Github.

You can open issues for bugs you've found or features you think are missing. You can also submit pull requests to this repository or submit translations using Crowdin. To get started, take a look at CONTRIBUTING.md. If your contributions are accepted into Mastodon, you can request to be paid through our OpenCollective.

IRC channel: #mastodon on irc.libera.chat

readabilityObject.textContent:
Hometown: a Mastodon fork

Photo by Joana Mujollari, CC0 / Public Domain.
Mastodon is a free, open-source social network server based on ActivityPub. This is not the official version of Mastodon; this is a separate version (i.e. a fork) maintained by Darius Kazemi. For more information on Mastodon, you can see the official website and the upstream repo.
Hometown is a light weight fork of Mastodon. This fork is based on the principle of: minimum code change for maximum user experience change. By our best understanding, our major changes are not wanted by the Mastodon project, hence maintaining this fork instead of trying to commit the changes to Mastodon.
Please check out our wiki for a list of Hometown-exclusive features. Some but not all of these are covered in this document.
You can also find a list of running Hometown instances, don't hesitate to open an issue to add yours!
Support this project
Please consider supporting Hometown by pledging to my Patreon, which supports all my open source projects including this one!
Of course this project couldn't exist without Mastodon so maybe support the Mastodon project Patreon too.
Migrating from Mastodon to Hometown
Please see this article in the wiki for directions on migration from Mastodon to Hometown.
Local only posting
Mastodon right now is designed to get your messages out to the entire fediverse. This is great, but there is a huge need for more private communities. And in a federated network I think it makes the most sense for your home server to be that community (hence "Hometown").
In the context of Hometown, local only posting is a per-post security option that lets you set whether that post can federate out to other servers or not.
I've been running Friend Camp, a Mastodon fork with local only posting, for about a year. Being able to have conversations with people on your server that don't federate is a hugely liberating thing. It allows inside jokes to develop. It allows people the freedom to complain about things that they wouldn't necessarily feel comfortable leaving a trusted server (cops, employers, etc). It also lets us do things like have a server-wide movie night where we flood the local timeline with posts about the movie, and it doesn't pollute the rest of the Fediverse.
This feature is based on the work of Renato Lond, which is itself based on a feature in the Mastodon Glitch Edition fork.
Reading more content types
Mastodon is microblogging software, meant for Twitter-style shortform posting.
Hometown is microblogging for writing, but its goal is to accept many content types for reading. So while I don't plan to let Hometown users publish massive blog posts, I would like your Hometown instance to be your one-stop shop for viewing all sorts of things on the Fediverse.
For Hometown this means if you subscribe to a service that sends out Article objects over ActivityPub (such as a blog on Write As), then those full articles render in your home timeline, behind a cut for length. Also, Hometown will render a variety of rich text like italic and bold.
Click on this GIF for a brief video demo:

This is based on rich text work by Claire Girka, and my own work on Article support.
It's more than just reading more stuff
Reading more content types also helps make the fediverse better. ActivityPub supports all kinds of content, but most ActivityPub servers shoehorn all their content into Note because that's the type that Mastodon treats as first-class. This has important implications for the fediverse and also on your day to do user experience.
Take the "quote tweet" debate for example.
Twitter has a feature called "quote tweeting" that lets you embed what someone else tweets, with your own comment right next to it. It's really useful for provide commentary in context, like this, where I point people to a sale and they can read both my comment on the sale and the original tweet about the sale in one post:


Hometown doesn't support quoting articles yet... but it will.

Better list management
If Hometown is going to be a universal reader, you're going to need better control over organizing your feeds than mainline Mastodon provides.
I've introduced a new kind of exclusive list. In vanilla Mastodon, if you add an account to your "friends I like" list, posts from people on that list appear on that list. But they also appear on your home timeline, and maybe you don't want that! You'd rather treat your "friends I like" list as your "real" home timeline, and then check your home timeline when you're bored. Check out more details about exclusive lists on the wiki.
Better accessibility defaults
Look, right now this pretty much just means that we underline hyperlinks by default. I'm of course open to implementing other obviously beneficial accessibilty defaults that Mastodon itself doesn't implement.
Hometown is still 99.999% Mastodon
I don't intend to stray very far from mainline Mastodon with this fork. If you want something that provides a ton of new features and widgets and stuff, the Mastodon Glitch Edition fork is a wondrous kitchen sink of major and minor tweaks.
Part of why I don't want to stray far from mainline Mastodon is that this project is going to be just me for the foreseeable future, and I'd like to keep it up to date with new Mastodon versions as easily as possible. The less code I change from Mastodon, the easier that is. Hence the principle of "minimum code change for maximum user experience change."
Versioning
Hometown uses semantic versioning and follows a versioning convention like v1.0.0+2.9.3. The 1.0.0 part is the actual Hometown version number, and then the 2.9.3 after the + sign is what's known in semantic versioning as "build metadata". It just means that a particular release is synchronized with Mastodon version 2.9.3, so for example an upgrade from v1.0.0+2.9.2 to v1.0.0+2.9.3 would upgrade Mastodon but not provide any new Hometown features or fixes.
Contributing to Hometown
Setting up your Hometown development environment is exactly like setting up your Mastodon development environment. Pull requests should be made to the hometown-dev branch, which is our default branch in Github.
You can open issues for bugs you've found or features you think are missing. You can also submit pull requests to this repository or submit translations using Crowdin. To get started, take a look at CONTRIBUTING.md. If your contributions are accepted into Mastodon, you can request to be paid through our OpenCollective.
IRC channel: #mastodon on irc.libera.chat
